title: Processing data
text: In the processing phase, the data will be undergoing the mostly automated steps for processing, before the analysis and interpretation.

questions.title: Will you need a shared working space to work with your data?
How will you work with your data?
questions.text: There are several questions regarding the dynamics of the data in the working area, who works with it, the software that is run on it, etc.

questions.title: What kind of data will you have in your work space?
questions.text: When making the work space, it helps to know whether you expect to work with very many small files, a few very large files, whether you will use a (SQL) database to store most of the data. Maybe your data is suitable for a system like Hadoop? Such information can be collected here.

questions.title: Do you need the work space to be close to the compute capacity?
questions.text: If you have large volumes of data that are intensely and repeatedly used by the computing work flow, it may be needed to keep the storage in the same place as where the computing takes place.

questions.title: Will you be working with your data in another form than the way it will be archived?
questions.text: Archival and working with data have different requirements. You want archived information to be in a form that others could read and in a format that is also understandable in a number of years. When working with the data, you need to be able to address it efficiently. If the two differ, you need to plan for conversions.

answers.label: No, data format will be archived in the same way we work with it
Yes, archival will require a conversion step

questions.title: How does the storage need change over time?
questions.text: To perform capacity planning, it is important to know what the need for storage capacity at the beginning and the end of the project will be.

answers.label: Storage needs will be the same during the whole project
Storage needs are large at the beginning and will be reduced later
Storage needs are small at the beginning and will grow later
Storage needs are largest in the middle of the project

questions.title: When will your raw data become available?

answers.label: Raw data will come in right at the start
Raw data will come in during the project

questions.title: How much of the raw data do you need to keep in the work space?
questions.text: Sometimes the raw data is relatively large, and it pays of to clean it quickly.

answers.label: Raw data will need to stay in the work space
Raw data can be cleaned out or archived quickly
Raw data do not form a major part of the storage needs
Raw data will only be loaded in the work space on demand from the primary archives

questions.title: Do your raw data need to be archived?

answers.label: No, it is also stored elsewhere can be recovered easily
No, it can be remeasured easily and more cheaply than archiving

questions.title: Did you plan how much intermediate data you will get during analysis and how long each step needs to be kept?

answers.label: The volume of intermediate data will not be significant
A large volume of intermediate data will be in the work space

questions.title: Is it possible to store intermediate temporary data on a separate (scratch) area that is not backed up?
questions.text: If the intermediate results are in your main work space, a restore in case of a problem could take much more time. It may be faster to recover it by re-running computations

answers.label: We will use the main work space for temporary data
We can offload intermediate results to a scratch area that is not backed up

questions.title: Are you sure you will not need a backup of the data stored on the scratch file systems (any scratch you use)?

references.anchor: How CSC restored 850 million temporary files

questions.title: Will you have different versions of intermediate data that need to be kept?
questions.text: Consider storing only the workflow parameters if the data itself could be reproduced quickly

questions.title: Will you need to temporarily archive data sets (e.g. to tape)?
questions.text: Usually, data sets will be archived if it is unlikely you need them in the short term, but it would be hard to create them again, and/or they are essential for reproducing your work. Archival storage of large volumes can be significantly cheaper than keeping it in the working area for an extensive period.

questions.title: How will your first data come in?

answers.label: No special planning is needed for the initial data
Initial data will need to be made available through a local network copy
We will need a high-speed network connection to copy the initial data
Initial data will arrive on separate media and will need to be copied to the work space

questions.title: How will project partners access the work space?
Who will arrange access control?

answers.label: Project management will need to be able to give people access
The work space should be connected to a single-sign-on system

questions.title: Will the work space storage need to be remote mounted?

answers.label: No, data will be copied if it needs to be processed elsewhere
No, all data processing will be done in the same environment (virtual research environment)
Yes, for actual computations, requiring high performance

questions.title: Will data be copied out and in to the workspace storage by remote users?

answers.label: No, this should not be allowed
No, all data processing will be done in the same environment (virtual research environment)
Yes, for actual computations, requiring high performance

references.description: Workflow that is split over multiple work locations

questions.title: Are data integrity and reliability requirements also met by the other storage spaces used in the project?
How available/reliable should must the work space be?
questions.text: There are a number of questions that can help you to decide whether your work space will be reliable enough for your project.

questions.title: What is the acceptable risk for a total loss?

answers.label: All essential data is also stored elsewhere

questions.title: Is there software in the work space? Can it also be restored quickly?

answers.label: Software in the work space is only a copy
Special care will be taken for the software and configurations

questions.title: Can you handle it when the work space is off line for a while?

answers.label: We could handle a few days of offline time per year
We can only miss the work space for a few hours during work hours
Problems during the evenings and weekends can not wait for work hours to be repaired

questions.title: How long can you wait for a restore if the storage fails?

answers.label: We can wait for repair and a restore
A spare copy needs to be deployed quickly
No waiting is possible, a hot copy must be ready to take over

questions.title: How long can you wait for a restore if you accidentally damage a file?

answers.label: Any user needs to be able to restore an old copy instantaneously

questions.title: Will you make backup copies of project data that is not in the work space?
questions.text: Are there any data files e.g. on laptops of project members? Also: supercomputing centers and other high performance computer centers often write in their terms of use that you need to take care of your own backups

answers.label: This is left to the project participants
All data elsewhere is adequately backed up
We make (automated) backups of all data stored outside of the working area

questions.title: Are data all project members store adequately backed up and traceable?

answers.label: Yes, protected against both equipment failure and human error

questions.title: Workflow development
questions.text: It is likely that you will be developing or modifying the workflow for data processing. There are a lot of aspects of this workflow that can play a role in your data management, such as the use of an existing work flow engine, the use of existing software vs development of new components, and whether every run needs human intervention or whether all data processing can be run in bulk once the work flow has been defined.

questions.title: Will you be exploring parameters to the workflow, or run in bulk?
questions.text: What will be the operational mode for your workflows? Will you be exploring options by changing tools and tweaking parameters? Of will you be running the same exact workflow on a large number of data files?

answers.label: We will be exploring parameters to the workflow
We will be running in bulk

questions.title: What data will the workflow developers or implementers use?
questions.text: The people implementing the data analysis work flow for your project probably need test data that they can use to see whether what they build works. How will this be arranged?

answers.label: They can use existing data from another project
They can use data from our project

questions.title: When will they have access?

answers.label: Data will be available at the start of the project, no waiting needed
They can start with a subset as soon as our first data comes
Workflow development will commence as soon as our data is available
answers.advice: Take this into account when doing the time planning for the critical path

questions.title: How will data security be dealt with?

answers.label: Data security is not an issue
Data will not be on systems owned by workflow developers

questions.title: What other arrangements?
List existing software components you will use in the analysis workflow
questions.text: Your workflow may be available in components from different sources. Specify the different parts that you recognize and that you will each acquire in a different way

questions.title: Where are you getting this software from? Please specify a web address if available.
What version of this software will you use?

answers.label: The exact version that we point to
The current version, and we will stick with that
Whatever is the latest version at the time the analysis is run

questions.title: Will you re-run any analysis when a new version comes out?

answers.label: If there is potentially a better result
answers.advice: Make sure to take that into account when calculating the need for compute resources

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: Make sure to take that into account when calculating the need for compute resources

questions.title: How is your experience with this software?

answers.label: We will gather experience by visiting others who have used it

questions.title: List new software components you will develop for the analysis workflow
questions.text: Not all components you need may be available already. Please list here what you will be developing yourself. Do not underestimate the time needed to integrate components into a work flow!

questions.title: Please specify the software repository you use for development
questions.text: Preferably use a direct URL other users could use

questions.title: Did you consider existing options?

answers.label: Authors of similar alternatives are not willing to work with us
Alternatives exist, but we prefer to develop our own
This will be one of the prime distinctive outcomes of our project

questions.title: What license will you use for your tool?
questions.text: Make sure the license is compatible with all components you use, and also make sure the license is made explicit in the repository.

answers.label: We are using a different license

questions.title: What other license?
questions.text: Preferably give a web pointer to the license.

questions.title: Is this a recognised reusable open source license?
Did you choose the workflow engine you will be using?

answers.label: Workflows will be run from a computer command line
Yes, we will be using what we always use
answers.advice: Make sure that you are not missing out on alternatives that would have better properties for the project

answers.label: Yes, we have selected one based on what features we need

questions.title: Do you need the workflow engine to produce provenance information automatically?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does the provenance need to be stored or converted to some standard format?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Can the work flow be annotated to make it understandable?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Do you need the workflow engine to be run high-throughput?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Is ease of development of the workflow engine itself an issue for you?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Can you reach out to the developers? Is there a contact?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does the workflow engine need to support a particular compute back end you will use?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does the workflow engine need standard tools for administrators?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Is ease of development of the workflows an issue for you?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does the workflow engine need a developer GUI?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does it need to be easy to support new tools in a workflow?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does it need support for specific kinds of data processing or data integration pipelines?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does it need support for complex control structures like conditionals and/or loops?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does it need native support for specific data types?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does it need  support for nested workflows?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Does it need  support collaborative editing of workflows?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Is ease of use an issue for you?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Who are the people that will run the workflows?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

answers.label: Subject matter experts with a strong computer knowledge
Subject matter experts with no affinity for computer solutions

questions.title: Does the running of work flows need to be controlled via a GUI?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Do work flows need to be run on remote computers?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Is durability of work flows important for you?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Do you need the same workflow to run next year? Durability against 'workflow decay'?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Are all versions of all tools, including built-in tools, under total control of the project?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Do you need to be able to export/import workflows (e.g. in the Common Workflow Language, CWL)?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Do you want your workflow engine to be professionally hosted by a specialized party?
questions.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

questions.title: Can you make a decision for the workflow engine based on the criteria deemed important?

answers.label: We will need more than one engine

questions.title: Do you plan taking special measures to guaranty the integrity of tools in the workflow?
Will you only use well-scrutinized open source tools?
Will you have all changes checked by a second developer before deploying them?
How will you handle upgrades to tools?

answers.label: We will trust a new release and deploy
We will offer multiple versions of tools for the end user to choose
We will only deploy selected stable upgrades to tools
We will test all tool changes on a subset of our own data before deployment
We will not change tool versions after the initial selection
answers.advice: Please consider how you will be solving issues/problems you find yourself and that are fixed in a new release

questions.title: Will you test whether known correct results are obtained over time?

answers.label: Yes, we will regularly make test runs on the same data
Yes, we will automatically make test runs on the same data

questions.title: Are all tools you use under your complete control?

answers.label: No, we use tools maintained by others
Yes, we only use tools that we can maintain ourselves

references.description: Control over tools in the workflow engine

questions.title: How will you deal with the situation where support for a tool is dropped?

answers.label: We will keep running it unchanged
We will start to do necessary maintenance ourselves

questions.title: How will you make sure to know what exactly has been run?
Will you keep results together with all processing scripts or workflows including documentation of the versions of the tools that have been run?
Will you make use of the metadata fields in your output data files to register how the data was obtained?
questions.text: File formats like VCF (for genetics) and TIFF (for images) have possibilities to document metadata in the file header. It is a good idea to use work flow tools that use these fields to document what was done to obtain the data.

questions.title: Will you use a central repository for all tools and their versions as used in your project?
questions.text: Especially if analysis and processing of data in the project is done on multiple different computers by different people, it is a good idea to have your own repository of tools and their blessed versions.

questions.title: Will you use a central repository for reference data used in your project?
questions.text: Especially if analysis and processing of data in the project is done on multiple different computers by different people, it is a good idea to have your own repository of reference data versions.

questions.title: Will you make use of standard workflow engines and automatic work flows for all data analysis in the project?
questions.text: It is much easier to guarantee consistency and reproducibility if all data processing is done using automated work flows, especially if the workflow engine automatically keeps adequate provenance data.

references.description: Provenance as selection criterion for workflow engine

questions.title: Are all software tools in the work flow professionally maintained, with version control?
questions.text: Will you be able to find and reproduce exactly which version was used for any analysis? Not only for the major tools in the workflows, but also for all 'glue' code and small tools you created especially for the project?

questions.title: How will you validate the integrity of the results?
Will you run a subset of your jobs several times across the different compute infrastructures you are using?
questions.text: There are surprisingly many complications that can cause (slight) inconsistencies between results when workflows are run on different compute infrastructures. A good way to make sure this does not bite you is to run a subset of all jobs on all different infrastructure to check the consistency.

questions.title: Will you be instrumenting the tools into pipelines and workflows using automated tools?
questions.text: Surrounding all tools in your data processing and analysis workflows with the 'boilerplate' code necessary on the computer system you are using is tedious and error prone. Especially if you are using the same tools in multiple different work flows and/or on multiple different computer architectures. Automated instrumentation, e.g. by using a workflow management system, can prevent many mistakes.

questions.title: Will you use independently developed duplicate tools or workflows for critical steps to reduce or eliminate human errors?
questions.text: Validation of results without a golden standard is very hard. One way of doing it is to develop two solutions for a problem (two independent workflows or two independently developed tools) to check whether the results are identical or comparable.

questions.title: Will you run part of the data set repeatedly to catch unexpected changes in results?
questions.text: Running a small subset of the data repeatedly can be useful to catch unexpected problems that would otherwise be very hard to detect.

questions.title: Do you need to do compute capacity planning?
questions.text: If you require substantial amounts of compute power, amounts that are not trivially absorbed in what you usually have abailable, some planning is necessary. Do you think you need to do compute capacity planning?

questions.title: Do you know how much CPU power, memory and I/O band width a typical analysis will take?
questions.text: Did you run pilot jobs? Do you know this information from comparable projects? Did you test whether the work scales up as you expected if you run more than one job?

questions.title: What type of compute architecture is most suitable for your work? Will you have that available?

answers.label: We will use a compute cluster
We will use a mix of computing architectures for different parts of the work

questions.title: Is there sufficient experience with the chosen computer in the project, and sufficient time to support the project partners?

answers.label: Our people will be able to call for help
We have sufficient knowledge in the project

questions.title: Have you established with the provider when will you need the compute capacity?
questions.text: Do you need the compute capacity also for development? Can you start developing locally and start with a deployment test later?

questions.title: Is all required compute capacity available close to the project working storage area?
Did you plan the required network capacity between storage and compute services?

answers.label: There are no special networking requirements
Copying or network delays are considered to be acceptable
We will be able to use a dedicated network connection

questions.title: Can all data be legally transported and processed at the computing site?
questions.text: Are the risks of data leaks covered?

questions.title: Will different groups work on different parts of the workflow? Will parts of the computing be done on 'local' infrastructure to the group?

answers.label: All steps of the workflow will be performed at central computing locations
Some steps may be performed at local computing locations

references.description: Copying data into and out of the main working area of the project

questions.title: Is there sufficient network capacity to the other computing locations?
Is the risk of information loss, leaks and vandalism acceptably low?
questions.text: There are many factors that can contribute to the risk of information loss or information leaks. They are often part of the behavior of the people that are involved in the project, but can also be steered by properly planned infrastructure.

questions.title: Do project members store data or software on computers in the lab or external hard drives connected to those computers?
questions.text: When assessing the risk, take into account who has access to the lab, who has (physical) access to the computer hardware itself. Also consider whether data on those systems is properly backed up

questions.title: Do project members carry data with them?
questions.text: Does anyone carry project data on laptops, USB sticks or other external media?

questions.title: Are all data carriers encrypted? Are accounts on the laptop password protected?
Do project members store project data in cloud accounts?
questions.text: Think about services like Dropbox, but also about Google Drive, Apple iCloud accounts, or Microsoft's Office365

questions.title: Do project members send project data or reports per e-mail or other messaging services?
Do all data centers where project data is stored carry sufficient certifications?
Are all project web services addressed via secure http (https://)?
Have project members been instructed about the risks (generic and specific to the project)?
questions.text: Project members may need to know about passwords (not sharing accounts, using different passwords for each service, and two factor authentication), about security for data they carry (encryption, backups), data stored in their own labs and in personal cloud accounts, and about the use of open WiFi and https

questions.title: Did you consider the possible impact to the project or organization if information is lost?

answers.label: Yes; the risk is acceptably low
Yes; we will need to work on this.

questions.title: Did you consider the possible impact to the project or organization if information leaks?

answers.label: Yes; the risk is acceptably low
Yes; we will need to work on this.

questions.title: Did you consider the possible impact to the project or organization if information is vandalized?

answers.label: Yes; the risk is acceptably low
Yes; we will need to work on this.

questions.title: Do you have a contingency plan?
questions.text: What will you do if the compute facility is down?

answers.label: We will wait until the problem is fixed
